study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pycnogenol on cognitive performance in elderly participants, as well as explore potential cardiovascular and biochemical mechanisms over 12 months.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Pycnogenol's effects, as the study appears to be ongoing or results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Elderly participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Pycnogenol for treating various chronic disorders, including asthma, ADHD, chronic venous insufficiency, diabetes, erectile dysfunction, hypertension, and osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support Pycnogenol's efficacy for any chronic disorder due to small sample sizes, limited trials per condition, and variability in outcomes. No definitive conclusions on safety or efficacy were possible.
population_specificity: Adults and children with chronic disorders (asthma, ADHD, chronic venous insufficiency, diabetes, erectile dysfunction, hypertension, osteoarthritis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Pycnogenol (PYC) in reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and synaptic protein loss following traumatic brain injury (TBI) in rats.
results_summary: PYC treatment significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (protein carbonyls, lipid peroxidation, protein nitration), mitigated synaptic protein loss, and lowered proinflammatory cytokine levels (IL-6, TNF-α) compared to vehicle-treated controls. Some hippocampal protein levels in PYC-treated animals were comparable to sham-operated controls.
population_specificity: Young adult Sprague-Dawley rats with moderate cortical contusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) could protect against liver damage caused by oxidative stress and fat accumulation in a model of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation prevented hepatic macrovesicular steatosis and fibrosis, significantly reduced liver triglyceride levels, and lowered serum alanine aminotransferase levels in MCD-fed rats. The results suggest PYC may help prevent NASH-induced liver damage.
population_specificity: Rats fed a methionine-choline deficient (MCD) high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol improves endothelial dysfunction, a precursor to atherosclerosis, in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved endothelial function (measured by flow-mediated dilatation) and reduced oxidative stress, but had no effect on inflammation markers, platelet adhesion, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: 23 patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Pycnogenol for treating various chronic disorders, including asthma, ADHD, chronic venous insufficiency, diabetes, erectile dysfunction, hypertension, and osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support Pycnogenol's efficacy for any chronic disorder due to small sample sizes, limited trials per condition, and variability in outcomes. No definitive conclusions on safety or efficacy were possible.
population_specificity: Adults and children with chronic disorders (asthma, ADHD, chronic venous insufficiency, diabetes, erectile dysfunction, hypertension, osteoarthritis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of Pycnogenol versus compression stockings in managing chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
results_summary: Pycnogenol was better tolerated than elastic compression in CVI patients, though specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 subjects with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Pycnogenol supplementation on finger pain associated with hand osteoarthritis compared to standard management alone.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly reduced spontaneous morning pain and pain after work compared to standard management alone, with no reported side effects or discontinuations.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from finger pain associated with hand osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the supplementary use of Pycnogenol® in managing minimal residual symptoms of systemic Lupus with vasculitis (LV) during remission phases, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® supplementation significantly reduced several symptoms (e.g., photosensitivity, oral ulcers, oxidative stress) and improved microvascular parameters compared to standard management alone, with no observed side effects. The supplement showed superior effects in reducing oxidative stress and improving peripheral perfusion.
population_specificity: Subjects with Lupus vasculitis (LV) in remission phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol® on penile fibrosis and associated symptoms, comparing its efficacy alone and in combination with Centellicum® against standard management.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® combined with Centellicum® significantly improved symptoms, erectile function, plaque characteristics, and oxidative stress compared to standard management. Both supplement groups showed better outcomes than the standard management group.
population_specificity: 82 subjects with penile nodules and plaques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) had protective effects against monosodium urate (MSU) crystal-induced inflammatory and nitrosative stress in joint tissues, both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PYC inhibited the upregulation of inflammatory markers (COX-2, IL-8, iNOS) and reduced NO production in chondrocytes and synovial fibroblasts. It also attenuated MSU-induced activation of NF-κB and MAP kinases in vitro and reduced inflammatory cell infiltration and marker expression in a rat model.
population_specificity: Human articular chondrocytes, synovial fibroblasts, and a rat model of acute gouty arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pycnogenol supplementation on cardiometabolic health through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and body mass index, suggesting potential benefits for cardiometabolic health. However, the study recommends further well-designed RCTs to confirm long-term effects and optimal usage.
population_specificity: 1,594 participants across 24 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effect of pycnogenol supplementation on systolic and diastolic blood pressure in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation reduced systolic blood pressure by -3.22 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure by -1.91 mmHg, with more pronounced effects when administered alongside other treatments and in studies lasting over 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults (922 participants across 12 clinical trials)
study_duration: Varied (subgroup analysis included studies ≤12 weeks and >12 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Pycnogenol, alone or combined with Centellicum, could reduce the progression of within-stent neointima in stented arteries over 12 months.
results_summary: Pycnogenol alone significantly reduced progression to higher arterial risk classes compared to standard management, and the combination with Centellicum further decreased progression rates. Oxidative stress was also significantly reduced in the supplement groups.
population_specificity: 160 subjects with stented arteries in arterial risk classes 2 or 3.
effective_dosage: Pycnogenol 150 mg/day; Centellicum 450 mg/day (in combination group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol on edema, thrombotic complications, and jet lag in individuals taking long-haul flights, stratified by thrombosis risk levels.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced edema and ankle circumference significantly across all risk groups, with no thrombotic events observed in the Pycnogenol groups. D-dimer levels remained normal in Pycnogenol subjects, and jet lag scores were lower compared to controls.
population_specificity: 450 subjects at varying thrombosis risk levels (low, moderate, high) flying in economy class for over 8 hours twice a week; 295 completed the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an L-arginine-based multi-ingredient product (AbMIP) on vascular function in individuals with elevated blood pressure and hyperhomocysteinemia.
results_summary: AbMIP significantly improved fasting endothelial function and reduced homocysteine levels and systolic blood pressure, though postprandial endothelial function improvements were not statistically significant. No significant effects were observed on HbA1c, ADMA, or diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: 25 male and female subjects aged 45–65 years with elevated blood pressure and hyperhomocysteinemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy in controlling cardiovascular risk factors, oxidative stress, and menopausal symptoms in peri-menopausal women.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly reduced cholesterol, triglycerides, fasting glucose, blood pressure, plasma free radicals, homocysteine, and CRP levels, while improving menopausal symptoms. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Peri-menopausal women with borderline cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol supplementation on cognitive function, attention, and mental performance in healthy older adults with high oxidative stress.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly improved cognitive function, daily task performance, and reduced oxidative stress compared to controls, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects aged 55-70 with high oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Pycnogenol could reduce the recurrence of retinal vein thrombosis (RVT) after a first episode compared to standard management or Aspirin.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced recurrent RVT (3.56% vs. 17.39% in controls) and improved vision (20/25 at nine months) with no reported side effects, while Aspirin had a higher dropout rate and minor hemorrhagic episodes.
population_specificity: Patients with a first episode of retinal vein thrombosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol supplementation improves cognitive function, attention, and mental performance while reducing oxidative stress in healthy professionals under increased oxidative stress.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly improved cognitive function, mood, and oxidative stress levels compared to controls, with notable enhancements in professional daily tasks and semi-professional minitasks. Plasma-free radicals decreased by 30.4% in the Pycnogenol group, while controls showed no significant change.
population_specificity: Healthy professionals aged 35-55 with increased oxidative stress, no risk conditions, or addictions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy in improving cochlear flow and symptoms in patients with Meniere's disease, tinnitus, and cochlear hypoperfusion over a 6-month follow-up.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved all registry items, cochlear flow velocity, and tinnitus symptoms compared to controls, with 87.3% of Pycnogenol users becoming asymptomatic by 6 months versus 34.6% of controls. The supplement also reduced lost working days.
population_specificity: Patients with Meniere's disease, tinnitus, and cochlear hypoperfusion (n=120, with 55 in the Pycnogenol group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Pycnogenol on lipid profile (total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, and triglycerides) through a meta-analysis of controlled clinical trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of Pycnogenol on any lipid parameters (total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, or triglycerides), with results remaining robust in sensitivity analyses. A dose-effect association was noted only for LDL-C, but no other associations were found between Pycnogenol dose or duration and lipid changes.
population_specificity: 442 patients (226 in Pycnogenol group, 216 in control group) from 7 controlled clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol supplementation could enhance cognitive function, attention, and mental performance in healthy students.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly improved sustained attention, memory, executive functions, and mood ratings in students over 8 weeks. The Pycnogenol group also performed better on university tests, with fewer failures and higher average scores compared to controls.
population_specificity: Healthy students aged 18-27 years.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of a low daily dosage of Pycnogenol for improving climacteric symptoms in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved most climacteric symptoms, particularly vasomotor and insomnia/sleep problems, with a 56% reduction in symptom severity compared to placebo's 39% after 12 weeks. A significant placebo effect was observed, but Pycnogenol outperformed placebo in multiple symptom categories.
population_specificity: 170 perimenopausal women (156 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol® supplementation could improve health risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome, including central obesity, elevated triglycerides, low HDL cholesterol, high blood pressure, and fasting blood glucose.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® supplementation (150 mg/day) significantly reduced waist circumference, triglyceride levels, blood pressure, and fasting glucose while increasing HDL cholesterol levels over 6 months. Plasma free radicals also decreased more effectively in the Pycnogenol group compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-55 years with all five risk factors of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol on physical fitness, exercise recovery, and oxidative stress in normal individuals and semi-professional athletes.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly improved physical fitness metrics (running time, push-ups, sit-ups) and reduced oxidative stress in normal individuals. In athletes, it enhanced triathlon performance, decreased cramps and pain, and accelerated metabolic recovery compared to controls.
population_specificity: Normal individuals (Part 1) and semi-professional triathlon athletes (Part 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy in alleviating signs and symptoms associated with menopausal transition.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced common menopausal symptoms (e.g., hot flushes, mood swings) and improved oxidative stress levels compared to the control group, with no reported side effects. Some symptoms showed improvement but lacked statistical significance versus controls.
population_specificity: 38 women in the intervention group and 32 in the control group, all experiencing menopausal transition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of a supplement containing Pycnogenol® and L-arginine in improving erectile dysfunction in Japanese patients.
results_summary: The supplement improved IIEF-5 scores, particularly in 'hardness of erection' and 'satisfaction with sexual intercourse,' while also reducing blood pressure and liver enzymes and slightly increasing salivary testosterone, with no adverse reactions reported.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with mild to moderate erectile dysfunction.
effective_dosage: Pycnogenol® 60 mg/day, L-arginine 690 mg/day, and aspartic acid 552 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current research on Pycnogenol, focusing on extraction methods, pharmacological, toxicological, and nutraceutical effects, and clinical studies.
results_summary: The study compiled 69 research articles, with most highlighting Pycnogenol's antioxidative properties and its role in cardiovascular health and other degenerative disorders. Two articles focused on extraction advancements, while the rest covered clinical, biological, and nutraceutical aspects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could relieve symptoms of birch pollen-induced allergic rhinitis and whether the timing of supplementation affected its efficacy.
results_summary: Pycnogenol showed significant improvement in eye (-35%) and nasal (-20.5%) symptoms compared to placebo when taken 5-8 weeks before allergen exposure, with better results observed in subjects who started supplementation 7-8 weeks prior. Birch-specific IgE levels increased less in the Pycnogenol group (19.4%) than in the placebo group (31.9%).
population_specificity: 39 subjects with birch pollen-induced allergic rhinitis in Ontario, Canada.
study_duration: 5-8 weeks prior to the birch pollen season

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of action, clinical trials, and routine clinical use of Pygeum africanum for treating lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostate hyperplasia.
results_summary: The review concluded that Pygeum africanum appears to be a viable option in urological treatment, though the evidence level is IV (based on expert opinion). The study did not provide strong clinical trial data but suggested its potential utility.
population_specificity: Patients with lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostate hyperplasia.

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness and tolerability of Pygeum (P. africanum) in improving lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and quality of life (QoL) in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) under real-world clinical conditions.
results_summary: After 6 months of treatment, Pygeum significantly reduced QoL impairment (22.6% vs. 45.2% at baseline) and improved overall IPSS scores (mean decrease of 4.5 points). High satisfaction and compliance were reported, with no treatment-related adverse effects.
population_specificity: 115 patients with LUTS/BPH

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Pygeum africanum on prostate cell growth in vitro using human serum collected before and after intake.
results_summary: The serum from a treated man reduced proliferation in primary, organotypic, and WPMY cells but not PNT2 cells. Transcriptome analysis showed upregulated tumor suppression genes and downregulated inflammation and oxidative-stress genes.
population_specificity: Human prostatic stromal myofibroblast cell line (WPMY), prostatic epithelial cell line (PNT2), and fresh benign prostatic tissue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to broaden the understanding of Pygeum africanum extract's safety profile, particularly regarding potential toxicological effects.
results_summary: The study found that Pygeum caused toxicological effects in rats, including increased liver weight, altered kidney markers (creatinine), and elevated LDH levels, suggesting potential harm to kidneys, skeletal muscle, or myocardium. Prostate weight reduction was observed, but safety concerns outweighed potential benefits.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms behind Pygeum africanum's antiproliferative and apoptotic effects on prostate stromal cells, comparing responses between BPH and non-BPH cells, and investigating interactions with growth factors and hormones.
results_summary: Pygeum exhibited stronger antiproliferative and apoptotic effects on BPH stromal cells than non-BPH cells, particularly targeting alphaSMA+ cells. It downregulated TGFB1 and increased sensitivity to FGF2, while VEGF, DHT, and E2 reduced its antiproliferative activity.
population_specificity: Primary prostate stromal cells from BPH/LUTS patients (n=3) and non-BPH patients (n=3).
interactions: Reduced sensitivity when combined with VEGF, DHT, or E2; TGFB1 and E2 blocked antiproliferative effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the active compound (NBBS) in Pygeum africanum that acts as an androgen receptor antagonist and evaluate its potential for treating prostatic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that NBBS, isolated from Pygeum africanum, acts as a specific androgen receptor antagonist, inhibiting AR-mediated transactivation and prostate cancer cell growth. Derivatives of NBBS were identified as more potent AR antagonists, suggesting therapeutic potential for prostatitis, BPH, and prostate cancer.
population_specificity: Human androgen receptor and prostate cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of Pygeum africanum on oxidative stress and functional changes in the bladder after diabetes induction in rats.
results_summary: Pygeum significantly increased catalase and superoxide dismutase activities, reduced malondialdehyde levels, decreased inducible nitric oxide synthase-positive cells, and improved bladder function in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar male rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg, orally in peanut oil daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify molecular targets of Pygeum africanum extract affecting prostate growth and bladder function, and to assess its clinical efficacy for lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: The study demonstrated in vitro and in vivo inhibition of growth factor-mediated prostate growth and improvement in bladder function parameters, with partial corroboration from short-term clinical efficacy. These findings support further large-scale clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) or lower urinary tract symptoms (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer potential of Pygeum africanum in prostate cancer prevention and treatment, both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Pygeum africanum extract inhibited growth and induced apoptosis in prostate cancer cells (PC-3 and LNCaP), downregulated key proteins, and reduced prostate cancer incidence by 35% in TRAMP mice compared to controls.
population_specificity: In vitro (PC-3 and LNCaP cells) and in vivo (TRAMP mouse model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate antiandrogenic compounds in Pygeum africanum, specifically atraric acid and its derivatives, for potential therapeutic use in prostate hyperplasia and prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study isolated atraric acid from Pygeum africanum and demonstrated its antiandrogenic activity via an androgen receptor responsive reporter gene assay. Derivatives of atraric acid (ethyl, N-propyl, and N-butyl esters) were also synthesized and tested, showing antiandrogenic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiandrogenic activity of Pygeum africanum extracts and identify compounds responsible for this effect, particularly for potential use in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostate cancer (PCa).
results_summary: A dichloromethane extract from Pygeum africanum stem bark showed the highest antiandrogenic effect in an AR-responsive reporter gene assay. Bioactivity-directed fractionation isolated N-butylbenzenesulfonamide (NBBS), suggesting androgen antagonistic activity in Pygeum extracts.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and urodynamic effects of a combination of Pygeum africanum and stinging nettle extracts in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical improvement, quality of life, or urinary flow rate between the phytotherapic combination and placebo groups after six months of treatment. The effects of the Pygeum and nettle combination were similar to placebo.
population_specificity: Men aged ≥50 years with BPH, urinary symptoms (IPSS ≥12), and a maximum urinary flow rate (Q(max)) between 5 and 15 mL/s.
effective_dosage: 25mg Pygeum africanum and 300mg stinging nettle extracts (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pygeum africanum is more effective than placebo, as effective as standard BPH treatments, and has fewer side effects compared to standard BPH drugs.
results_summary: Pygeum africanum showed moderate improvement in urologic symptoms and flow measures compared to placebo, with men twice as likely to report symptom improvement. Adverse effects were mild and comparable to placebo.
population_specificity: Men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
study_duration: Mean study duration was 64 days (range 30-122 days).

study_goal: To systematically review and meta-analyze the therapeutic efficacy and tolerability of Pygeum africanum in men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: Pygeum africanum showed a moderately large improvement in urologic symptoms and flow measures compared to placebo, with men twice as likely to report symptom improvement. Adverse effects were mild and similar to placebo, with a 12% overall dropout rate.
population_specificity: Men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pygeum (TAD) on micturition frequency/volume and prostatic weight in rats with DHT-induced prostate growth, comparing cotreatment and post-treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Pygeum cotreatment or post-treatment suppressed DHT-induced changes in micturition frequency and volume, and cotreatment partially regressed prostatic weight growth, though post-treatment did not reverse established growth.
population_specificity: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats with DHT-induced experimental prostate growth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and mechanisms of action of Pygeum africanum (Tadenan) as a phytotherapeutic treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: Pygeum africanum is widely used for BPH treatment, with clinical studies supporting its efficacy. The preparation is standardized and undergoes strict quality control, but effects cannot be generalized to nonstandardized extracts.
population_specificity: Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular effects of Tadenan (Pygeum africanum extract) on prostate fibroblast proliferation and bladder function, focusing on its impact on the adenylyl cyclase system in rats.
results_summary: Tadenan increased VIP-mediated adenylyl cyclase stimulation, enhanced alpha(i) activation, and elevated levels of various G-protein subunits in proliferating prostates, but had no effect on nonproliferating prostates. These findings suggest Pygeum may modulate prostate cell signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Castrated/testosterone-replaced rats with induced prostatic cell proliferation.
effective_dosage: 1 or 10 mg/kg body weight, administered twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the therapeutic profile of Pygeum africanum extract in treating mild to moderate BPH under daily practice conditions, using IPSS and flowmetry assessments.
results_summary: Pygeum significantly improved IPSS (40%), QoL (31%), and reduced nocturnal frequency (32%), with sustained effects one month post-treatment. Flowmetry parameters also improved, and no adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Men aged 50-75 with mild to moderate BPH (IPSS ≥ 12, QoL ≥ 3, max urinary flow ≤ 15 ml/s).
study_duration: 2 months of treatment, followed by 1 month without treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of half-dose versus full-dose urtica/pygeum preparation in treating symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: Both dosage groups showed significant reductions in urine flow, residual urine, and nycturia after 28 days, with further improvements after 56 days. No significant differences in efficacy were found between the half-dose and full-dose groups, and adverse effects were minimal.
population_specificity: Men aged 53 to 84 years with symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia, recruited from two medical centers in Warsaw.
effective_dosage: Two capsules of either standard dose (300 mg Urtica dioica + 25 mg Pygeum africanum) or half-dose, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of Pyritinol (Encephabol) compared to placebo in patients with cerebrovascular disorders.
results_summary: The study reported results from multiple controlled, double-blind trials, suggesting Pyritinol's efficacy in treating cerebrovascular disorders, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with a variety of cerebrovascular disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Pygeum Africanum extract (Tadenan) at double the standard dosage in patients with prostatic hypertrophy or chronic prostatitis, including those with associated sexual disorders.
results_summary: Pygeum improved urinary parameters and reduced peri-urethral edema, with some improvement in sexual behavior, but no significant changes in serum hormonal levels or nocturnal penile tumescence and rigidity (NPTR) were observed. No side effects were reported during the treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with prostatic hypertrophy or chronic prostatitis, some with concurrent sexual disorders.
effective_dosage: 200 mg per day (double the standard 100 mg/day dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pyritinol (800 mg daily) improves symptoms in patients with moderately advanced dementia compared to placebo.
results_summary: Patients on Pyritinol showed significantly higher levels of improvement than those on placebo, as measured by a modified Crichton Geriatric Behavioural Rating Scale. Laboratory tests remained normal for both groups, indicating no adverse effects.
population_specificity: 40 patients with moderately advanced dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Pygeum africanum extract in treating micturitional disorders caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia compared to placebo.
results_summary: Pygeum africanum extract significantly improved quantitative parameters (e.g., residual urine, uroflowmetry) and subjective symptoms of micturitional disorders, with 66% of treated patients showing improvement versus 31% in the placebo group. Gastrointestinal side effects occurred in 5 patients, leading to discontinuation in 3 cases.
population_specificity: 263 patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia-related micturitional disorders across 8 centers in Germany, France, and Austria.
effective_dosage: 50 mg extract (1 capsule morning and evening).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between Pyritinol dosage, treatment duration, and success rates in patients with chronic organic brain syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that higher doses and longer treatment durations significantly improved success rates, suggesting that exceeding the recommended daily dose may be beneficial in severe cases or when initial improvement is lacking. The retrospective analysis provided supplementary insights to controlled studies.
population_specificity: 161 patients with chronic organic brain syndrome (average age 64 years).
effective_dosage: Various oral doses (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: Various periods of time (specific duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report cases of pemphigus (a skin disorder) occurring during Pyritinol therapy for rheumatoid polyarthritis and memory deficiency.
results_summary: The study found two cases of pemphigus linked to Pyritinol use, with clinical and histological evidence confirming the diagnosis. Anti-intercellular substance antibodies were detected in both patients.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid polyarthritis and memory deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Pyritinol-HCl on cognitive functions in children with learning disabilities under double-blind conditions.
results_summary: Pyritinol-HCl showed no statistically significant treatment effects across 22 cognitive parameters compared to placebo, though variability in gainscores suggested differential effects among subjects. Prognostic stratification failed to identify criteria predicting positive treatment effects.
population_specificity: 67 children aged 11-16 years with learning disabilities in slow learner classes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pyruvate, as part of a metabolomic signature, could mitigate glaucoma risk in high-genetic-risk individuals and validate its protective effects in a mouse model.
results_summary: Pyruvate was linked to reduced glaucoma prevalence in high-genetic-risk individuals and demonstrated protective effects in mice by lowering intraocular pressure and optic nerve damage.
population_specificity: UK Biobank participants (4,658 glaucoma cases and 113,040 controls) and Lmx1bV265D mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether boosting mitochondrial respiration with pyruvate and scavenging ROS with uridine could ameliorate cardiac hypertrophy and bradycardia symptoms.
results_summary: Pyruvate plus uridine supplementation significantly prevented PE-induced cardiac hypertrophy, pericardial edema, and bradycardia in zebrafish embryos and reduced ventricular and atrial area in transgenic lines. The combination improved mitochondrial respiration and cell survivability in H9c2 cardiomyocytes.
population_specificity: Rat neonatal H9c2 cardiomyocytes and zebrafish embryos (including cardiomyocyte-specific GFP transgenic Tg (myl7:HRAS-EGFP) lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibitory efficacy, residence time, and ochronotic pigment accumulation of triketone compounds as potential 4-HPPD inhibitors for treating Alkaptonuria (AKU).
results_summary: The study found that triketone compounds demonstrated inhibitory efficacy against 4-HPPD and provided insights into their pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties, suggesting a promising foundation for safer and more effective AKU treatments.
population_specificity: The study focused on in vitro and in silico models, not a specific human population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Ethyl Pyruvate (EP) in promoting burn wound healing and preventing tissue necrosis in a rat model.
results_summary: EP demonstrated positive effects in reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and cell death, preserved the stasis zone, and accelerated healing in the coagulation area. The study concluded that EP administration effectively halted tissue necrosis and promoted wound healing due to its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced thermal burn injuries.
effective_dosage: Test 1 group received EP 30 min, 12, 24, 36, 48, 60, and 72 h post-injury; Test 2 group received a single dose of EP 30 min post-injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of SLIC-SABRE hyperpolarized [1-13C]pyruvate for metabolic MRI in cancer diagnostics, specifically assessing tumor metabolism and therapy response.
results_summary: The study found elevated lactate metabolism in tumors compared to healthy tissues, with distinct metabolic profiles in different tumor compartments, suggesting a link between lactate-to-pyruvate ratios and tumor cell proliferation/apoptosis.
population_specificity: Transgenic breast cancer mouse model (MMTV-PyMT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether PKM2 agonism (via pyruvate kinase M2 activation) enhances mitochondrial function and anti-tumor efficacy in CD8 and CAR-T cells, and its potential synergy with anti-PD1 therapy.
results_summary: PKM2 activation improved mitochondrial biogenesis, hypomethylated DNA, and enhanced CD8 T cell cytotoxicity and anti-tumor responses, synergizing with anti-PD1 therapy to boost tumor-specific T cell activation while reducing Treg cells.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (in vitro and in vivo studies involving CD8 T cells and CAR-T cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of desidustat, a HIF stabilizer, on pyruvate kinase activity, oxidative stress, and RBC parameters in models of beta-thalassemia and sickle cell disease.
results_summary: Desidustat increased hemoglobin, RBCs, and hematocrit in mice models, reduced iron overload and oxidative stress, and enhanced pyruvate kinase activity in RBCs of humans, mice, and rats. It also decreased sickling in sickle cell patient blood.
population_specificity: Beta-thalassemic mice (B6.D2-Hbbd3th/BrkJ), phenylhydrazine-induced hemolytic anemia in C57 mice, and sickle cell disease patient blood.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying TCS-induced liver damage, focusing on the role of pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) and its interaction with hnRNPA1 in hepatic stellate cell activation.
results_summary: TCS exposure increased PKM2 dimer levels by 200% in LX-2 cells, promoting hepatic stellate cell activation. Inhibition of PKM2 dimerization reduced this activation, suggesting the hnRNPA1/PKM2 axis as a key pathway in TCS-induced liver fibrosis.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice (offspring exposed from gestation to postnatal 8 weeks) and LX-2 cell line (human hepatic stellate cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: PKM2 plays a dual role in HCC by regulating cellular metabolism and oncogenic signaling pathways, promoting tumor growth, survival, and metastasis through interactions with PI3K/AKT/mTOR and MAPK pathways. Its inhibition may offer therapeutic opportunities to block tumor growth and improve clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients and related metabolic studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how pyruvate metabolism contributes to lymphatic metastasis in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and identify potential therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study found that activated pyruvate metabolism in HNSCC promotes tumor lymphangiogenesis via EPHB2 upregulation, independent of VEGF-C/VEGFR3 signaling. Targeting EPHB2 with EFNB1-Fc combined with VEGFR3 inhibitor effectively reduced lymphangiogenesis in preclinical models.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structure and transport mechanism of the human mitochondrial pyruvate carrier (MPC1L/MPC2 heterodimer) and its role as a drug target for various diseases.
results_summary: The study solved the structure of the human MPC1L/MPC2 heterodimer in inward- and outward-open states, revealing its rocker-switch mechanism and identifying a central pyruvate binding site. It also determined the binding poses of three inhibitor classes that mimic pyruvate interactions in the outward-open state.
population_specificity: Not specified (structural and mechanistic study, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combining pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) inhibitor CPI-613 with hexokinase 2 (HK2) inhibitor benserazide (Benz) to target the metabolic vulnerability of KRAS Q61H mutant-bearing NSCLC tumors.
results_summary: The combination of Benz and CPI-613 synergistically disrupted the hybrid metabolic state, inhibited NCI-H460 cell proliferation in vitro, and suppressed tumor growth in a xenograft model. It also restored sensitivity to SHP2 inhibitors by suppressing SHP2/SOS1/RAS/MAPK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: NCI-H460 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells harboring the KRAS Q61H mutation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prognostic significance of PKM2 expression in glioblastoma (GBM) and grade 4 astrocytoma (ASTROG4) and its correlation with survival and other molecular markers.
results_summary: PKM2 expression was observed in both GBM and ASTROG4, with high PKM2 intensity scores significantly correlating with increased mortality risk. ATRX-negative tumors showed elevated PKM2 levels, suggesting metabolic adaptations, and ASTROG4 cases had better survival outcomes than GBM.
population_specificity: 67 patients with high-grade gliomas (43 GBM, 24 ASTROG4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether impaired pyruvate kinase (PK) function is associated with sickle red blood cell (RBC) properties and clinical manifestations in sickle cell disease (SCD).
results_summary: The study found that reduced PK thermostability and PK/hexokinase (HK) ratio correlated with impaired sickle RBC properties (e.g., deformability, adhesion) and higher incidence of SCD-related clinical complications, suggesting PK activation therapy could be beneficial.
population_specificity: 97 non-transfused patients with SCD (88 HbSS, 9 HbS/β0 thalassemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) in modulating mitochondrial dynamics and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in alveolar epithelial cells (AECs) during sepsis-associated pulmonary fibrosis (PF).
results_summary: The study found that LPS exposure increased PKM2 and mitochondrial fission markers while reducing fusion and epithelial markers, which were reversed by shikonin treatment, restoring mitochondrial balance and reversing EMT markers, thereby alleviating sepsis-associated PF.
population_specificity: Alveolar epithelial cells (AECs) in the context of sepsis-associated pulmonary fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a data-driven kinetic fitting approach to accurately quantify hyperpolarized 13C-pyruvate metabolism in MRI, compensating for uncertainties in radiofrequency flip angles and other model parameters.
results_summary: The proposed method significantly reduced errors in pyruvate-to-lactate conversion rate (kPL) measurements, achieving median kPL errors within ±3% despite T1 uncertainties. In rat studies, it improved lactate signal fitting and reduced kPL standard deviation by 3.1-fold compared to uncorrected methods.
population_specificity: Rat liver and kidneys

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of β-3-hydroxybutyrate infusion on myocardial metabolic flexibility using hyperpolarized [2-13C]pyruvate MRS in pigs, focusing on alterations in TCA cycle flux and myocardial work.
results_summary: β-3-OHB infusion significantly increased cardiac output and heart rate, shifted metabolism towards increased lactate production, and decreased acetyl-carnitine and glutamate levels, demonstrating myocardial adaptability to ketone body utilization. These effects normalized post-infusion, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for heart failure.
population_specificity: Five female Danish landrace pigs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of sodium pyruvate in restoring mitochondrial enzyme activity and correcting metabolic dysfunction following blast trauma and hemorrhagic shock.
results_summary: Sodium pyruvate treatment restored mitochondrial enzyme activity (complex I, complex IV, and PDH) to near-baseline levels, corrected hyperlactatemia, and reduced ROS production in a preclinical rat model.
population_specificity: Preclinical rat model subjected to blast exposure with or without hemorrhagic shock.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a camelid single-domain antibody (sdAb) could selectively inhibit trypanosomatid pyruvate kinases to negatively impact parasite fitness and growth.
results_summary: The study found that the sdAb selectively inhibited trypanosomatid pyruvate kinases through an allosteric mechanism, impairing parasite fitness and growth, while not affecting host enzymes.
population_specificity: African trypanosomes (parasites causing neglected tropical diseases in humans and livestock).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pyruvate, as part of a metabolomic signature, could mitigate glaucoma risk in high-genetic-risk individuals and validate its protective effects in a mouse model.
results_summary: Pyruvate was linked to reduced glaucoma prevalence in high-genetic-risk individuals and demonstrated protective effects in mice by lowering intraocular pressure and optic nerve damage.
population_specificity: UK Biobank participants (4,658 glaucoma cases, 113,040 controls) and Lmx1b V265D mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified for humans; dietary pyruvate used in mice (exact dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Not specified for humans; intervention duration in mice not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enhancing oxidative phosphorylation (OxPhos) through PDK2 inhibition could improve metabolic flexibility in chondrocytes and reduce cartilage degeneration in osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: PDK2 deficiency in mice improved OxPhos, reduced oxidative stress and senescence in chondrocytes, and protected against cartilage damage and pain behaviors in an OA model. These effects were linked to restored metabolic function and reduced p38 signaling.
population_specificity: Mice with surgically induced osteoarthritis (DMM model) and IL-1β-treated chondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which Pyruvate carboxylase (PC) deficiency induces mitochondrial injury and metabolic reprogramming in renal tubular epithelial cells (RTECs) and its role in renal fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that PC deficiency in RTECs reduces interaction with SQOR, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, increased mtDNA release, activation of the cGAS-STING pathway, elevated glycolysis, and ultimately promoting renal fibrosis. These effects were demonstrated in both animal models and human kidney samples.
population_specificity: Fibrotic animal models (renal proximal tubule-specific Pcx gene knockout mice) and human kidney samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Pyruvate's (PF) potential to reduce PDK3-associated toxicity in neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's disease (AD), and its neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: PF effectively inhibited PDK3 activity, enhanced cell viability, reduced oxidative stress and apoptosis, and improved memory markers like BDNF, showing dose-dependent efficacy in an in vitro model of SCP-mediated toxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro model (cell-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a pyruvate kinase (PyK)-biosensor for early cancer screening and detection of kinase inhibitors, evaluating its inhibition mechanism.
results_summary: The biosensor demonstrated high sensitivity (2.11 ± 0.08 μA mM-1 cm-2) for phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) detection, excellent reproducibility, and the ability to detect shikonin at very low concentrations (0.1-4.0 pM). The inhibition mechanism of shikonin was characterized, including IC50 values and binding constants (Ki).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize pyruvate kinase (PK) properties in sickle cell disease (SCD) mouse models and assess the effects of a novel PK activator (compound A) on PK activity and sickling tendency.
results_summary: The study found that compound A increased PK affinity for phosphoenolpyruvate, raised PK/hexokinase ratios, and reduced 2,3-DPG levels in SCD mouse models. It also identified key differences in PK thermostability and activity between mice and humans.
population_specificity: Townes and Berkeley SCD mouse models (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Single dose of compound A (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether circulating pyruvate kinase M2 (PK-M2) levels are elevated in heart failure (HF) patients and assess their association with diagnosis and prognosis.
results_summary: HF patients had higher PK-M2 levels than controls, which correlated with HF severity and predicted worse outcomes (rehospitalization or cardiovascular death). PK-M2 levels decreased after HF treatment and added prognostic value beyond clinical predictors.
population_specificity: 222 patients with heart failure and 103 control subjects.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 2 years (interquartile range: 776 to 926 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 3025@ML (a liposomal formulation containing SRT3025) enhances the chemotherapeutic effect of Oxaliplatin (OXA) in bladder cancer by targeting metabolic pathways involving pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) and fatty acid synthase (FASN).
results_summary: The study found that 3025@ML significantly enhanced OXA's anti-tumor activity by reducing cell viability, increasing apoptosis, and inhibiting key metabolic regulators (PKM2 and FASN) via the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway. The combination therapy showed stronger effects than OXA alone.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer cell lines (T24 and 5637).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how GLS2 expression modifies the metabolism of glioblastoma cells, particularly its potential tumor-suppressive role.
results_summary: GLS2 overexpression led to extensive metabolic changes, including alterations in the TCA cycle, downregulation of PDH activity, and impacts on nucleotide levels and methylated metabolites, suggesting a regulatory role in linking glutamine and glucose metabolism.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma cells (LN-229 cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acetylation modification, particularly involving GlSIRT1 and pyruvate kinase (PK), plays a role in enhancing heat resistance in *Ganoderma lucidum* by increasing pyruvate content.
results_summary: The study found that heat treatment enhanced the interaction between GlSIRT1 and PK, reducing PK acetylation and increasing its activity, leading to higher pyruvate content. GlSIRT1 knockdown strains showed reduced PK activity and pyruvate levels, along with increased heat sensitivity.
population_specificity: *Ganoderma lucidum* (a fungal species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the mitochondrial pyruvate carrier (MPC) in glioblastoma (GBM) progression following standard temozolomide (TMZ) and radiation therapy (RT).
results_summary: The study found that MPC acts as a central metabolic regulator in post-treatment GBM, suppressing differentiation and enhancing mitochondrial metabolic activity. A BBB-permeable MPC inhibitor, MSDC-0160, augmented standard therapy, reducing relapse and prolonging survival in preclinical models.
population_specificity: Patient-derived models of glioblastoma (GBM) treated with TMZ and RT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the function and mechanisms of atractylodin (ATR) in mitigating PCOS symptoms, focusing on its effects on oxidative stress and ferroptosis.
results_summary: ATR improved hormone levels, estrous cycles, and ovarian morphology in PCOS mice. It also inhibited granulosa cell ferroptosis by regulating the PDK4-mediated JAK-STAT3 pathway.
population_specificity: Female mice with DHEA and high-fat diet-induced PCOS and DHEA-induced KGN cells (a human granulosa cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore fertility preservation strategies in a young girl with pyruvate kinase deficiency undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that ovarian tissue cryopreservation (OTC) was a viable fertility preservation method for the patient, with no observed negative impacts. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation normalized blood cell counts and bilirubin levels, though AMH remained below normal.
population_specificity: Six-year-old girl with pyruvate kinase deficiency and severe hemolytic anemia.
study_duration: Five months between OTC and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a PKM2-responsive peptide hydrogel platform (GP@Gel Nap-T) for targeted delivery of PTX and GDC0919 to enhance immuno-chemotherapy in NSCLC.
results_summary: The hydrogel system demonstrated sustained release of PTX and GDC0919 within NSCLC tissues, enhancing immune cell infiltration and reducing immunosuppressive cells, thereby improving the immuno-chemotherapeutic effect of PTX.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) models.

study_goal: The abstract does not explicitly state a research goal regarding salt; it mentions high salt intake as a risk factor for gastric cancer.
results_summary: The abstract identifies high salt intake as a risk factor for gastric cancer but does not provide specific study results on salt's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of gastric cancer risk factors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a dietary intervention to reduce salt intake and increase high-nitrate green leafy vegetable consumption among Malaysian adults with raised blood pressure.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of salt reduction, as it focuses on feasibility measures like recruitment, retention, and acceptability of the intervention.
population_specificity: Malaysian adults with raised blood pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of miso intake versus equivalent salt intake on sympathetic nerve activity, blood pressure, and heart rate.
results_summary: The study found that miso lessens the effects of salt on blood pressure compared to equivalent salt intake, and clinical observations showed no relationship between miso soup intake frequency and hypertension incidence. Basic studies suggested miso ingredients attenuate sympathetic nerve activity, lowering blood pressure and heart rate.
population_specificity: Japanese population (higher salt consumers compared to Westerners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of salt sensitivity in blood pressure and its link to cardiovascular events, focusing on immune system involvement and gut-related mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that high-salt diets increase inflammation, dendritic cell production of IL-6, and formation of IsoLG-protein adducts, driving T-cell production of IFN-γ and IL-17A, contributing to salt-induced hypertension. The gut was identified as a key site for sodium interaction.
population_specificity: Hypertensive and normotensive populations (mice model referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of nitroglycerin on oxytocin-desensitized and oxytocin-naïve human myometrium and the subsequent response to oxytocin dose-response testing in vitro.
results_summary: Nitroglycerin-induced relaxation did not differ between oxytocin-desensitized and oxytocin-naïve myometrial strips, but oxytocin-induced contractility was attenuated after nitroglycerin exposure, particularly in desensitized tissues.
population_specificity: Myometrial samples from 17 elective cesarean deliveries.
effective_dosage: Incremental concentrations of nitroglycerin (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and acceptability of a text messaging intervention (TEXT4BP) to improve treatment adherence and lifestyle changes, including salt intake, among hypertensive patients in Nepal.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding salt's effects, as the study is a feasibility trial and the outcomes (e.g., salt intake, blood pressure) will be measured at baseline and 3 months.
population_specificity: Clinically diagnosed hypertensive patients aged 18-69 years in Nepal, currently receiving blood pressure-lowering medication for more than 3 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified (text messages were sent three times a week for 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between modifiable lifestyle factors, including salt intake, and the incidence of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Higher salt intake was associated with significantly increased odds of CKD (OR, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.06 to 1.38), indicating a negative effect on kidney health. The evidence was consistent but of low to very low certainty.
population_specificity: Adults without CKD at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between sodium intake and cardiovascular disease, and assess the potential benefits of salt substitution as an intervention.
results_summary: The study found that excess sodium intake elevates blood pressure and is linked to cardiovascular disease, with salt substitution showing comparable blood pressure reduction to single-drug therapy. It also suggested that the disease burden from sodium may be underestimated and that further clinical data are needed to confirm benefits and risks.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for those at risk of cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the clinical management challenges of systemic pseudohypoaldosteronism (PHA), a rare salt-wasting syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that systemic PHA requires high-dose oral replacement therapy and life-long management, but does not provide specific results regarding salt's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic pseudohypoaldosteronism (PHA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in extracellular fluid and blood pressure regulation, including its extra-renal mechanisms in salt-sensitive hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that ENaC, expressed in immune cells like dendritic cells, contributes to salt-sensitive hypertension via extra-renal mechanisms. It also highlighted ENaC's potential as a novel therapeutic target for hypertension.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on cellular and molecular mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile existing literature on halotherapy's use in chronic respiratory diseases and evaluate its potential benefits as an adjuvant therapy.
results_summary: Halotherapy showed improvement in pulmonary function measures (e.g., forced expiratory volume, forced vital capacity) and respiratory health-related quality of life, with relatively few or no adverse effects. More structured research, such as randomized clinical trials, is needed to establish guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of TRP channels in taste and pain perception, including their potential relationship with sensory experiences like those involving salt.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about salt but discusses the broader role of TRP channels in taste and pain signaling, highlighting their importance in nutrient acquisition and harm avoidance. Dysfunctional TRP channels are associated with taste perception issues and pain-related conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of TRP channels in sensory perception).

study_goal: The researchers sought to explore the mechanisms by which salt consumption increases blood pressure and the potential role of inflammation and green propolis in mitigating these effects.
results_summary: The study highlights the association between excessive salt consumption and hypertension, suggesting involvement of the immune system and proposing green propolis as a potential therapeutic target due to its anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of modern society's salt consumption and hypertension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions, including increased salt intake, for treating orthostatic hypotension in elderly individuals and those with neurological conditions.
results_summary: The review found mixed results for non-pharmacological interventions, including increased salt intake, with some showing potential benefits but not all resulting in clinically meaningful changes.
population_specificity: People aged 50 years and older, and individuals aged 18 years and older with neurological conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the link between salt-losing tubulopathies (Gitelman's and Bartter's syndromes) and altered ACE2 glycosylation, potentially affecting SARS-CoV-2 infection mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that GS/BS patients exhibit high Ang II levels with blunted cardiovascular effects and altered ACE2 glycosylation due to TGN/post-Golgi pH misregulation, suggesting a common mechanistic basis for overlapping clinical phenotypes.
population_specificity: Patients with Gitelman's syndrome (GS) and Bartter's syndrome (BS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document salt consumption patterns and evaluate the implementation and potential impact of salt reduction initiatives in Africa.
results_summary: The study found high salt intake among African adults (6.8–11.3 g/d), high salt levels in foods, and limited translation of consumer knowledge into behavior change. Modeling indicated significant health and cost benefits from salt reduction, but adoption of such initiatives remains slow.
population_specificity: Adults in 18 African countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of thermotherapy plus neck stabilization exercise versus neck stabilization exercise alone on pain, neck disability, muscle properties, and alignment in elderly individuals with chronic nonspecific neck pain.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Salt.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with chronic nonspecific neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of normal saline (NS) versus balanced salt solutions (BSS) in various clinical settings, focusing on adverse effects and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: NS was associated with hyperchloraemic acidosis and transient renal injury but showed no significant difference in mortality compared to BSS. BSS demonstrated physiological benefits, but larger trials are needed to confirm clinical superiority.
population_specificity: Patients in intensive care units (ICUs), major surgeries, renal transplants, and emergency departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between health literacy (HL) and dietary intake of salt, as well as whether HL moderates the efficacy of interventions promoting healthy salt intake.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of any association between HL and salt intake. One intervention study on sugar intake (not salt) concluded that HL was not a significant moderator of effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from observational and intervention studies).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the safety, tolerability, and feasibility of subretinal transplantation of hESC-derived RPE cells in patients with Stargardt macular dystrophy (SMD).
results_summary: The study found no serious adverse events over 3 years, with favorable functional and anatomical outcomes compared to the natural course of SMD. One patient showed improved visual acuity, while others remained stable.
population_specificity: Three patients with Stargardt macular dystrophy (SMD) and central visual acuity no better than 20/400.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review molecular inhibitors of the WNK-SPAK/OSR1-NCC pathway as potential treatments for Gordon's syndrome, a form of hypertension caused by increased NaCl reabsorption.
results_summary: The study highlights that thiazide diuretics, the current treatment for Gordon's syndrome, have side effects and compensatory adaptations, prompting research into novel inhibitors targeting the WNK-SPAK/OSR1-NCC pathway to reduce NaCl reabsorption and restore normal blood pressure.
population_specificity: Individuals with Gordon's syndrome, a form of secondary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a culturally appropriate color photograph (CP) elicits longer and more complex utterances than a black-and-white line drawing (LD) in neurologically healthy native Bangla speakers during a picture description task (PDT).
results_summary: The study found that grammatical complexity (measured by mean length of utterances, MLU) was significantly higher when using a CP compared to an LD, though no significant differences were observed for complexity index (CI), total number of words (TNW), or words per minute (WPM). The results suggest CPs may enhance spontaneous language production in healthy adults and potentially benefit individuals with aphasia.
population_specificity: 30 neurologically healthy native Bangla speakers (mean age 36.03 years) with no known cognitive, language, vision, or hearing impairments, middle socioeconomic status, and at least 12 years of formal education.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved visual stimuli, not salt consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current evidence on sodium chloride monitoring and supplementation needs in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF), particularly focusing on risks of sodium deficiency and metabolic alkalosis.
results_summary: The study highlights that CF patients, especially infants, are at risk for severe sodium deficiency due to high sweat losses and low intake, potentially leading to metabolic alkalosis. It notes a lack of specific recommendations and calls for more research on sodium status assessment and supplementation efficacy in the context of CF treatment advancements.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis (CF), with a specific focus on infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reduced-sodium, added-potassium salt substitutes effectively lower blood pressure in hypertensive patients in rural India.
results_summary: The study successfully recruited participants and is positioned to assess the effects of salt substitution on blood pressure, urinary sodium, and potassium levels, though final results are not yet reported. Baseline data indicate excessive sodium intake in the population.
population_specificity: Rural Indian adults aged ≥18 years with a history of hypertension.
effective_dosage: Salt substitute (70% sodium chloride and 30% potassium chloride) used to replace all household cooking and seasoning salt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between dietary sodium intake and cognitive outcomes, including cognitive function, risk of cognitive decline, or dementia in middle- and older-aged people.
results_summary: The study found mixed associations between sodium levels and cognition, with some evidence suggesting high salt intake is linked to poor cognition. A lower sodium intake was associated with improved cognition in one clinical trial, but methodological limitations and inconsistent results were noted.
population_specificity: Middle- and older-aged individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate interventions, including salt-coating, for decontaminating surgical masks to enable reuse, focusing on germicidal effects and mask performance.
results_summary: Salt-coated masks demonstrated good germicidal effects, but mask performance and safety outcomes were not thoroughly evaluated. The study noted heterogeneous test conditions and limited evidence on safety or efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on surgical mask decontamination, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of kidney tubular HDACs in maintaining fluid-electrolyte balance during high-salt diets and the potential adverse effects of HDAC inhibitors.
results_summary: The study found that kidney epithelial HDAC1 and HDAC2 are essential for maintaining fluid-electrolyte balance during high-salt intake, and HDAC inhibitors increased the risk of fluid-electrolyte disorders like hypokalemia. High-salt feeding in rats led to hypertension, polyuria, hypokalemia, and nitric oxide deficiency when class I HDACs were inhibited.
population_specificity: Rats and murine models, with implications for critically ill humans based on HDAC inhibitor meta-analysis.

study_goal: The study does not focus on Salt but rather on cystic fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD) and its management, including dietary recommendations.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings specific to Salt; it primarily discusses CFRD diagnosis, complications, and treatment, including a diet that does not restrict salt.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis, particularly those with or at risk for CFRD.

study_goal: To evaluate the short-term effectiveness of reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration salt (ORS) combined with propranolol in children with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).
results_summary: The study found that the combination of reduced-osmolarity ORS and propranolol significantly reduced syncopal attacks and improved orthostatic intolerance symptom scores compared to the control group. The treatment group showed better symptom improvement than the untreated control group.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (n=70) diagnosed with POTS via head-up tilt testing (HUTT).

study_goal: The researchers examined the anti-hypertensive effects of SGLT2 inhibitors and GLP1-receptor agonists in type 2 diabetic patients, suggesting their potential role in blood pressure control.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Salt's effects, focusing instead on the benefits of SGLT2 inhibitors and GLP1-receptor agonists for cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with arterial hypertension.

study_goal: To review the pharmacology, efficacy, and safety of ferric maltol (FM) as an oral iron formulation for treating iron deficiency anemia (IDA).
results_summary: FM demonstrated significant improvements in anemia and serum iron parameters in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD), with common adverse effects being gastrointestinal intolerance. It was found to be noninferior to intravenous ferric carboxymaltose in patients with IBD and IDA.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) with iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of scheduled versus as-needed posthospitalization follow-up visits in reducing parental anxiety for children hospitalized with bronchiolitis.
results_summary: The study found that as-needed follow-up visits were noninferior to scheduled visits in reducing parental anxiety, with no significant differences in secondary outcomes like readmissions or symptom duration. The as-needed group had fewer clinic visits.
population_specificity: Children younger than 24 months hospitalized for bronchiolitis at two children's hospitals and two community hospitals.
study_duration: Follow-up was assessed 7 days after hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of salt restriction on blood pressure and cardio-renal prognosis in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: Salt restriction reduced blood pressure and enhanced the anti-proteinuric effect of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors in non-dialysis CKD patients, but long-term effects on cardio-renal prognosis were controversial due to measurement bias and poor adherence. In end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), a low-salt diet is recommended to manage fluid overload and hypertension despite lack of efficacy trials.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients, including non-dialysis and end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of a high-sodium meal on vascular function and whether an antioxidant cocktail could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The study found that a high-sodium meal impaired endothelial function and increased arterial stiffness and wave reflection, but these effects were mitigated by the antioxidant cocktail.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (20 males, 21 females; average age 24 ± 1 years; BMI 23.4 ± 0.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: High-sodium meal (1500 mg) and antioxidant cocktail (vitamin C, E, alpha-lipoic acid).
study_duration: Acute effects measured over 120 minutes post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two practical sodium reduction strategies (stepwise salt supply control and salt substitute) on systolic blood pressure and safety outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it is designed to assess changes in systolic blood pressure and secondary outcomes like hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, cardiovascular events, and death over 24 months. The abstract suggests the study is well-positioned to provide important data on these outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 71 years, 76% male) in senior residential facilities in northern China.
effective_dosage: Stepwise salt supply control (5%-10% reduction every 3 months) and salt substitute replacing normal salt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to raise awareness of electrolyte disturbances, particularly salt imbalances, in pediatric cystic fibrosis (CF) patients.
results_summary: The study highlighted that young CF patients are at higher risk for acute electrolyte decompensation due to increased salt and fluid losses, presenting four pediatric cases to illustrate this issue.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).

study_goal: The researchers sought to summarize the evidence for increased salt intake in patients with orthostatic intolerance syndromes, focusing on its effects on symptoms, blood pressure, and heart rate.
results_summary: Increased salt intake improved time to presyncope, raised systolic blood pressure, and reduced heart rate during head-up tilt, with symptom improvement in 62.3% of participants. However, studies were small, short-term, and of low methodological quality, with no data on long-term outcomes or safety.
population_specificity: Patients with orthostatic intolerance syndromes, including orthostatic hypotension, syncope, postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, and idiopathic orthostatic tachycardia (n=391, mean age 35.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cytotoxicity of root canal filling materials using tetrazolium salt-based tests (like MTT) with other cell viability assays.
results_summary: MTT and XTT assays showed moderate to good concordance with other cell viability tests, indicating they do not over- or underestimate cell viability during cytotoxicity screening of root canal filling materials. The study suggests these assays are reliable for this purpose but recommends further development of protocols for 3D tissue-like cultures.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using animal and/or human cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess incident rituximab use over time in an integrated health care delivery system, focusing on FDA-approved and off-label indications.
results_summary: The study found that off-label use of rituximab increased significantly from 1.2% in 2009 to 55.6% in 2017, with neurologic conditions being the most common off-label indication. Factors like increased age and chronic disease burden were associated with receiving rituximab for FDA-approved indications.
population_specificity: Patients who received their first rituximab infusion between October 1, 2009, and December 31, 2017, in an integrated health care delivery system, excluding clinical trial participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the formulation development, properties, and challenges of intravenous (IV) nanosuspensions for poorly water-soluble drugs, including salt formation as one approach.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that salt formation, among other methods, is used for solubilizing poorly water-soluble drugs but has limitations such as hypersensitivity, toxicity, and applicability to specific molecules. IV nanosuspensions are presented as a promising alternative, though challenges remain in their translational development.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of scleral buckling (SB) and drainage-injection-pneumoretinopexy (DIP) for treating severe superior bullous rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (SBRD).
results_summary: Both SB and DIP showed a 93% primary anatomic success rate and significantly improved visual acuity, though DIP was less traumatic but associated with longer persistence of subretinal fluid. The study concluded both methods are safe and effective for severe SBRD.
population_specificity: 58 eyes with severe SBRD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of the intestinal microbiota-FXR axis in metabolic diseases and its potential as a drug target.
results_summary: The study found that intestinal microbiota regulates FXR activity, influencing bile acid composition and metabolic balance, suggesting the microbiota-FXR axis as a promising target for metabolic disease treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a culturally tailored education intervention to reduce salt intake and blood pressure among Filipino Americans.
results_summary: The intervention showed a non-statistically significant decrease in urine sodium levels and a reduction in systolic blood pressure (12.6 mmHg) in the intervention group, while the control group saw an increase (5.3 mmHg). Diastolic pressure also decreased in the intervention group (3.8 mmHg) but increased in controls (5.6 mmHg).
population_specificity: Filipino Americans living in the Greater Philadelphia Area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to classify Bartter's syndrome (BS) subtypes and understand its molecular basis and long-term consequences.
results_summary: The study identified different subtypes of BS (types I, II, and III) caused by gene mutations and highlighted the importance of early diagnosis to prevent complications like growth failure and end-stage renal disease.
